attachments.displayName:
An unusual way to win trust.

Apologizing for what, in fact, is not your fault (such as traffic congestion or problems with appliances), you'll seem more reliable. “Asking for an apology for the fact that, obviously, is not your fault , you take the position a person, who suffer from the circumstances , recognizing that something bad had happened to him , and expressing regret " - explains study co-author Alison Brooks.
Such behavior will cause people sympathy, and, as a result - they will begin to trust you more.
If you're trying to make contact with a new client, or interest a woman on a first date, just apologize for what is not your fault. This will increase your reliability in their eyes. Just do not go too far with an apology; an excessive number of them may seem annoying or insincere.
